description: A general survey, designed for the non-major, of the facts and theories of the astronomical universe, from solar system, to stars, to galaxies and cosmology. Topics include planets, satellites, small objects in the solar system, and extraterrestrial life; stars, their evolution, and their final state as white dwarfs, neutron stars, or black holes; galaxies, quasars, large structures, background radiation, and big bang cosmology. Elementary algebra and geometry will be used. This course is not recommended for physical-science majors or engineering students.
name: SURVEY OF THE UNIVERSE

values.comments:
This course is a general survey, designed for the non-major, of the facts and theories of the astronomical universe, from solar system, to stars, to galaxies and cosmology. Topics include planets, satellites, small objects in the solar system, and extraterrestrial life; stars, their evolution, and their final state as white dwarfs, neutron stars, or black holes; galaxies, quasars, large structures, background radiation, and big bang cosmology. Elementary algebra and geometry are used.

Most students really did enjoy the course, stating that the course was “awesome,” that there was “really fun material” and emphasizing that overall they had “an enjoyable semester.” One student called it “the best learning experience I’ve had at Penn.”

While some students complained about the material, they were unanimous in their praise of Professor Devlin. Students complimented Professor Devlin, stating that he was a “fantastic professor,” “knowledgeable” and “great.” Students also emphasized his sense of humor, saying he was “hilarious” and “engaging and funny.”

Some students protested that they felt “stressed out” over the new material and that there was “too much math.” Students in this course were generally taking it to fulfill a general requirement, and the course is open only to non-science majors.
